metadata.title: Convert MB/s to Mbps – Bandwidth & Throughput Accurate
metadata.description: Convert megabytes per second (MB/s) or mebibytes per second (MiB/s) to megabits per second (Mbps/Mib/s) with standards-based byte-to-bit math for downloads, SLAs, and lab tests.

mb_s_to_mbps_decimal.label: MB/s to Mbps (decimal)
mb_s_to_mbps_decimal.description: For file transfer speeds and ISP marketing values using decimal prefixes; multiplies by 8 per the 8-bit byte definition from NIST and ISO/IEC 80000-13.

mib_s_to_mibps_binary.label: MiB/s to Mib/s (binary)
mib_s_to_mibps_binary.description: For OS counters and engineering tools using binary prefixes; multiplies by 8 to convert mebibytes per second to mebibits per second.

fields.label: Throughput in MB/s
fields.helpText: Use for decimal megabytes per second from file transfers or ISP marketing; 1 MB = 1,000,000 bytes.

fields.label: Throughput in MiB/s
fields.helpText: Use for binary mebibytes per second shown in OS monitors or engineering tools; 1 MiB = 1,048,576 bytes.

introduction: Translate MB/s or MiB/s to Mbps or Mib/s instantly so you can align file transfer readouts, SLA documents, and lab measurements without guessing the byte-to-bit factor.
The calculator uses the standard 8 bits per byte and separates decimal versus binary prefixes to keep reports consistent with NIST, ISO/IEC 80000-13, and IEEE guidance.
Helper text keeps network engineers, QA teams, and students on the right track when reconciling marketing bandwidth with real-world throughput.
methodology: Decimal rates: multiply MB/s by 8 to get Mbps because 1 byte = 8 bits and MB/Mb use SI prefixes (10^6). This matches NIST SI guidance.
Binary rates: multiply MiB/s by 8 to get Mib/s using IEC/ISO 80000-13 binary prefixes (2^20 for mebi).

Pick the path that matches your source: file transfer apps and marketing copy are usually decimal, while OS performance counters or certain engineering tools may use binary. Note the prefix choice in any SLA or audit trail as recommended by IEEE 1541.
examples: 12.5 MB/s × 8 = 100 Mbps, matching the theoretical ceiling of a 100 Mbps link.
125 MB/s × 8 = 1000 Mbps (1 Gbps), useful for sanity-checking gigabit ethernet tests.
50 MiB/s × 8 = 400 Mib/s when reading a binary-prefixed throughput counter.

faqs.question: Why multiply by 8 to get Mbps?
faqs.answer: There are 8 bits in a byte. MB/s is bytes per second; multiplying by 8 gives bits per second using the NIST and ISO definitions.

faqs.question: Should I use Mbps or Mib/s?
faqs.answer: Use Mbps for decimal sources (marketing, ISPs, many speed tests). Use Mib/s when your tool shows binary prefixes. Consistency avoids reporting errors.

faqs.question: Do protocol overheads change this?
faqs.answer: Overheads from Ethernet, TCP/IP, TLS, and application framing reduce real-world throughput. This conversion is theoretical; expect lower observed speeds depending on stack and conditions.

faqs.question: Is this acceptable for SLA reporting?
faqs.answer: Yes. Using the 8-bit byte with documented prefix choice aligns with NIST and ISO/IEC 80000-13. Note whether you used decimal or binary in the SLA record.

faqs.question: Can I reverse from Mbps back to MB/s?
faqs.answer: Yes. Divide Mbps by 8 for MB/s (decimal) or divide Mib/s by 8 for MiB/s (binary) to stay consistent with your source units.

glossary.definition: Decimal data rate equal to 1,000,000 bytes per second.
Decimal data rate equal to 1,000,000 bits per second.
